author: Robert Stickles
subject: Re: Rupan on DVD?!
body:
>From: Arsene Lupin III <talesofthewolf@yahoo.com>
>Reply-To: lupin AT mcs DOT kent DOT edu
>To: lupin AT mcs DOT kent DOT edu
>Subject: Re: [lupin] Rupan on DVD?!
>Date: Fri, 22 Sep 2000 09:39:45 -0700 (PDT)
>
> > I hope Manga decides to at least release "Lupin's
> > Greatest Capers" on
> > Bilingual dvd.
>
>They'd probably redub it with their crappy Jigen and
>Zenigata.
>
> > Actually, X should have rotted in Japan. There are X
> > fans who hate it.
> > That's why there's even a tv show in the works.
>
>That doesn't have anything to do with the fact that it
>took Manga forever to bring it out domestically.
>
>
> > Time will tell. If he had the inside track that
> > Manga was buying any Lupin,
> > he should be right about Mamo. Hopefully if they do
> > buy it they'll call it
> > by it's original name, "Lupin vs the Clone".
>
>I have mixed feelings about that. While I feel a
>film's American title should usually be an accurate
>translation of the Japanese title, this is a
>challenge, and I can understand why Streamline changed
>it... it gives away a major plot point! Lupin does not
>even mention cloning until about halfway through the
>film, when Mamo reveals a LOT of stuff to them... it's
>a theatrical thing, I hope you understand. So, if it
>DID get released domestically, I think it should be
>under the title that is was released in Japan (to
>begin with, not the title it was later dubbed "Lupin
>vs. The Clones), which was "Lupin the Third". I think
>an English release of "Lupin III: The Movie" or
>something to that effect, should be adequate. Then the
>subtitle for the film's intro would be the accurate
>"Lupin the Third." And no problems with giving away
>plot points. Tadaa!

I thought it was later given the title "Lupin vs Fukeshi Ningen" in Japan 
after Cagliostro was released.  My Japanese isn't that good, but I think 
that translates into "Lupin vs Immortal Men".  That title doesn't give away 
as much of plot as the "Clone" title.  Is there a japanese word for "clone" 
or is it a katakana like "ko ro n"?  The story I heard for how the title 
Mystery of Mamo came about was that it was coined by an american translator 
who made up the name.  In fact, there was a previous Lupin villian called 
Mamo (Mamoo?) from the second TV series.

While we're on the topic of this film, I heard rumors that an english 
semi-profesional fan dub of this does exist with a script that is very 
faithful to the original script and characters.  This was apparently made in 
the early 80's or very late 70's.  Can anyone shed some light on this?

-Rob S.
